title: How to Find the Area of a Rectangle: Length x Width & Pythagorean Theorem

steps.title: Understand the rectangle.
steps.content: Understand the rectangle. The rectangle is a quadrilateral, which means it has four sides. [2] X Research source Its opposite sides are equal in length, so the sides along its length are equal, and the sides along its width are equal as well. If one side of the rectangle is 10, for example, then the opposite side's length will also be 10. Also, every square is a rectangle, but not all rectangles are squares. So treat squares like rectangles in terms of finding its area.

steps.title: Learn the equation for finding the area of a rectangle.
steps.content: Learn the equation for finding the area of a rectangle. The equation for finding the area of a rectangle is simply A = L * W. [3] X Research source This means that the area is equal to the length of the rectangle times its width.

steps.title: Find the length of the rectangle.
steps.content: Find the length of the rectangle. In most cases, you will be given the length, but if not, you can find it using a ruler. [4] X Research source [5] X Research source Note that the double hash marks on the long sides of the rectangle mean that the lengths of the two sides are the same.

steps.title: Find the width of the rectangle.
steps.content: Find the width of the rectangle. Use the same methods to find it. [6] X Research source Note that the single hash marks on the wide sides of the rectangle mean that the two widths have equal length.

steps.title: Write the length and width next to each other.
steps.content: Write the length and width next to each other. In this example, the length is 5 cm and the width is 4 cm.

steps.title: Multiply the length times the width.
steps.content: Multiply the length times the width. Your length is 5 cm and your width is 4 cm, so you should plug them into the equation A = L * W to find the area. [7] X Research source A = 4 cm * 5 cm A = 20 cm^2

steps.title: State your answer in square units.
steps.content: State your answer in square units. Your final answer is 20 cm^2, which means "twenty centimeters squared." [8] X Research source You can write your final answer in one of two ways: either 20 cm.sq. or 20 cm^2.

steps.title: Understand the Pythagorean theorem.
steps.content: Understand the Pythagorean theorem. The Pythagorean theorem is a formula for finding the third side of a right triangle if you know the value of two of the sides. You can use it to find the hypotenuse of a triangle, which is its longest side, or its length or width, which meet at a right angle. [9] X Research source Since a rectangle is comprised of four right angles, the diagonal that cuts through the shape will create a right triangle, so you can apply the Pythagorean theorem. The theorem is: a^2 + b^2 = c^2, where a and b are sides of the triangle and c is the hypotenuse, or longest side. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Use the Pythagorean theorem to solve for the other side of the triangle.
steps.content: Use the Pythagorean theorem to solve for the other side of the triangle. Let's say that you have a rectangle with a side of 6 cm and a diagonal of 10 cm. Use 6 cm for one side, use b for the other side, and take 10 cm as your hypotenuse. Now just substitute your known quantities into the Pythagorean theorem and solve. Here's how to do it: [11] X Research source Ex: 6^2 + b^2 = 10^2 36 + b^2 = 100 b^2 = 100 - 36 b^2 = 64 square root (b) = square root (64) b = 8 The length of the other side of the triangle, which is also the other side of the rectangle, is 8 cm.

steps.title: Multiply the length times the width.
steps.content: Multiply the length times the width. Now that you've used the Pythagorean theorem to find the length and width of the rectangle, all you have to do is multiply them. [12] X Research source Ex: 6 cm * 8 cm = 48 cm^2

steps.title: State your answer in square units.
steps.content: State your answer in square units. Your final answer is 48 cm^2, or 48 cm. sq.
